item.title: How the America's Cup embraced technology - CNN
item.description:
How the America's Cup embraced technology  CNN

Using helicopters and drones, the America's Cup been at the forefront of technological advances in TV. MARK LLOYD/AFP/AFP/Getty Images A container doubling as a technology studio is the hub for the team working the cutting-edge graphics. Ainhoa Sánchez The brainchild of Stan Honey, the advancements for 2013 lend themselves to a one-off conversation with Larry Ellison back in 1995. AFP/AFP/AFP/Getty Images Data is passed from telemetry on the boats to helicopters, to give the public a better understanding of the race's complexities. MARK LLOYD/AFP/AFP/Getty Images Fresh innovations loom for ...

item.title: New Zealand beat USA to win 35th America's Cup - live updates - The Telegraph
item.description:
New Zealand beat USA to win 35th America's Cup - live updates  The Telegraph

Helmsman Peter Burling and Emirates Team New Zealand have won the America’s Cup by routing software tycoon Larry Ellison’s Oracle Team USA. The underfunded but resourceful Kiwis claimed the oldest trophy in international sports on the Great Sound on Monday, winning Race 9 to clinch the match at 7-1. Team New Zealand started with a negative point because Oracle won the qualifiers, forcing the Kiwis to win eight races to return the Auld Mug to the Royal New Zealand Yacht Squadron in Auckland for the first time since 2003. The Kiwis atoned for their mind-numbing collapse in 2013, when they ble...

item.title: America's Cup 2017: Team-by-team guide - The Telegraph
item.description:
America's Cup 2017: Team-by-team guide  The Telegraph

27 Apr 2017 America's Cup 2017: Team-by-team guide Previous slideNext slide1 of 7View AllSkip Ad Ben Ainslie recommences his bid to win the 35th America's Cup next month when racing gets under way at Bermuda's Great Sound on May 26. Miles Dilworth casts an eye over his competition. Back to image

item.title: An America's Cup victory at our first attempt would be an historic achievement, but we are here for the long haul - The Telegraph
item.description:
An America's Cup victory at our first attempt would be an historic achievement, but we are here for the long haul  The Telegraph

This is it, then. Qualifying for the 35th America’s Cup begins in Bermuda on Friday, weather permitting. I say weather permitting as a cold front threatens to postpone the opening salvos but we’re not too concerned about that. As sailors, the weather obviously plays a huge part in our sport but hopefully the race schedule can remain on target. Regardless, I have no doubt that this will be a spectacular America's Cup. The big question for all of the teams right now is how does their race speed compare to the opposition? There is a famous saying from the America's Cup that ‘the fastest boat a...

item.title: America's Cup in pictures: Ben Ainslie's final preparations as clock ticks down to opening day - The Telegraph
item.description:
America's Cup in pictures: Ben Ainslie's final preparations as clock ticks down to opening day  The Telegraph

26 May 2017 America's Cup in pictures: Ben Ainslie's final preparations as clock ticks down to opening day Previous slideNext slide1 of 9View AllSkip Ad Despite the gale force winds that have caused the opening day of racing to be postponed until Saturday, conditions on Bermuda's Great Sound have been good for most of practice racing. Here are a selection of some of the more stunning shots as Sir Ben Ainslie's Land Rover BAR team aims to become the first British crew to win the America's Cup. Back to image

item.title: America's Cup: Lionheart wins Superyacht Regatta in Bermuda - CNN
item.description:
America's Cup: Lionheart wins Superyacht Regatta in Bermuda  CNN

Lionheart came from behind on a thrilling final day of racing to claim both the J Class and overall honors in the America's Cup Superyacht Regatta, hosted by Boat International Media. The Lionheart crew started the third day behind Ranger, but a third place was enough to clinch the double in Bermuda. ACEA 2017 / Boat International Media Lionheart's tactician Bouwe Bekking, a seven-time around-the-world racer, said: "We are delighted. We want to win all the races we ever do. That's why we do it, isn't it?" ACEA 2017 / Boat International Media In the fleet of six J Class yachts, Ranger eventu...

item.title: A Comprehensive Look at Watch Brands Involved in the 35th America's Cup - Forbes Now
item.description:
A Comprehensive Look at Watch Brands Involved in the 35th America's Cup  Forbes Now

The races are on as we ready for the 35th America’s Cup Presented by Louis Vuitton. Well, at least the qualifier races are on, but on Monday, June 6, the Louis Vuitton America’s Cup Challenger Playoffs begin, and run until June 12 as five teams race to the finish to determine which one will become the Challenger for the Cup, the oldest trophy in international sports. America’s Oracle Team USA is the Defender of the Cup (for the third time in a row). Here we bring you the most comprehensive look at the five watch brands that are involved in the precision timing of the teams and the races – a...

item.title: America's Cup Qualifiers 2017: race schedule - when is Ben Ainslie racing? - The Telegraph
item.description:
America's Cup Qualifiers 2017: race schedule - when is Ben Ainslie racing?  The Telegraph

In order to qualify for the America's Cup Match against Oracle Team USA, which begins on 17 June, one of the five challenging teams will be eliminated during the America's Cup qualifying stage. Oracle Team USA will compete in this round of the tournament, partly in order to gain match racing practice, but also because the winner of the qualifiers will begin the America's Cup Match with a one-point advantage, if they make it past the next round that is. The six teams race each other twice, scoring one point for a victory. America’s Cup World Series winners - Sir Ben Ainslie's Land Rover BAR...

item.title: No clear favourite as Americas' Cup draws near - The Telegraph
item.description:
No clear favourite as Americas' Cup draws near  The Telegraph

Bernie Wilson for Associated Press The America's Cup trials start two weeks from Friday on Bermuda's Great Sound, and the man in charge of sailing's marquee regatta doesn't believe there's an overwhelming favorite, not even two-time defending champion Oracle Team USA. Russell Coutts has been watching practice races between the 50-foot, foiling catamarans. He said he's impressed with Oracle Team USA, Artemis Racing of Sweden, SoftBank Team Japan and Emirates Team New Zealand, the hard-luck loser in the 2013 America's Cup on San Francisco Bay. "I actually don't think there is a clear favorite...

item.title: Iain Percy insists Artemis Racing can complete America's Cup comeback - The Telegraph
item.description:
Iain Percy insists Artemis Racing can complete America's Cup comeback  The Telegraph

They threw away a healthy advantage in their first race and lost a man overboard in their last. But Iain Percy – the British tactician aboard Artemis Racing – said on Saturday night he was confident the Swedish team could overhaul Emirates Team New Zealand in their first-to-five series to determine who would challenge USA for the 35th America’s Cup. Percy revealed he had been speaking with Sir Ben Ainslie, the vanquished skipper of the British team who lost 5-2 to the Kiwis in the playoff semi-finals, and they had agreed that the New Zealand boat had certain “weaknesses” they could exploit....

item.title: OracleVoice: Team New Zealand Jumps Out To Early America's Cup Lead - Forbes Now
item.description:
OracleVoice: Team New Zealand Jumps Out To Early America's Cup Lead  Forbes Now

ROYAL NAVAL DOCKYARD, BERMUDA—The much-heralded America’s Cup grudge match between two-time defending champion ORACLE TEAM USA and Emirates Team New Zealand started as the Cup finals did four years ago, with the Kiwis jumping out to an early lead, winning the first two races on Saturday, Day 1 of the international sailing competition. ORACLE TEAM USA may have felt the effects of not racing for almost two weeks, while the Kiwis had fought through a competitive Challenger series to make it to the Match finals. On Day 1 of the finals, the “puffy” wind conditions on Bermuda’s Great Sound were c...

item.title: Kiwis wrest America’s Cup from Oracle Team USA - Financial Times
item.description:
Kiwis wrest America’s Cup from Oracle Team USA  Financial Times

The America’s Cup has been won in emphatic style by New Zealand, the underdogs who ‘pedalled’ their way to victory in revolutionary style in the contest for the oldest trophy in international sport. Emirates Team New Zealand, led by skipper Glenn Ashby and helmsman Peter Burling, were on match point at 6-1 after two race victories on Sunday over software billionaire Larry Ellison’s Oracle Team USA, the two-time defending champions led by skipper Jimmy Spithill. Victory in the first race on Monday secured sailing’s most prestigious prize. Bill English, the New Zealand prime minister, congrat...

item.title: Emirates Team NZ out to ruin Sir Russell Coutts' best-laid plans as battle for the America's Cup begins - The Telegraph
item.description:
Emirates Team NZ out to ruin Sir Russell Coutts' best-laid plans as battle for the America's Cup begins  The Telegraph

The stormy weather that put paid to Friday’s opening day of racing at the 35th America’s Cup had passed through by Saturday morning, leaving Bermuda resplendent in sunshine once again and ready to get down to the serious business of qualifying. The undercurrents that threaten to drag this Cup into a bare-knuckle fight between Emirates Team NZ and defenders Oracle Team USA will be harder to shake. They have been bubbling beneath the surface for some time now; the legacy of years of sniping and mistrust between the America’s Cup’s two biggest beasts, its two finalists from 2013. The way that ...

item.title: Omega's America's Cup Sponsorship Pays Off As Team New Zealand Advances To Final - Forbes Now
item.description:
Omega's America's Cup Sponsorship Pays Off As Team New Zealand Advances To Final  Forbes Now

Like the Olympic Games or soccer’s World Cup, sailing’s America’s Cup ranks as one of the world’s premier sporting events. It’s a combination of prestige, passion, and affluence. These qualities, along with the elite-level of followers and supporters, keep the America’s Cup — held every four years — among the top sporting events for companies who spend millions sponsoring it. It’s why many companies such as luxury watchmaker Omega SA, a subsidiary of Bienne, Switzerland-based Swatch Group, recently signed an extension to continue sponsoring Emirates Team New Zealand, a team they have suppor...

item.title: Record-breaking speed sailor has plans for 'crazy boat' - CNN
item.description:
Record-breaking speed sailor has plans for 'crazy boat'  CNN

Walvis Bay, 2012. Flamingos soar over the Namibian coastline as the fastest sailor in history flies by at 78mph. A decade of work, unwavering belief and dedication to the cause is crystallized in a single record-breaking moment. Welcome to the Bonneville Salt Flats of speed sailing. Meet Paul Larsen, pilot of the Vestas Sailrocket 2. " width="612">Five years on To this day, no other sailing vessel has exceeded 60 knots (69mph) over the 500-meter distance specified by the World Sailing Speed Record Council. Having tipped speeds of 67 knots, Larsen and his team -- including Helena Darvelid an...

item.title: Oracle Team USA plot unlikely repeat - CNN
item.description:
Oracle Team USA plot unlikely repeat  CNN

Oracle Team USA skipper Jimmy Spithill faces an uphill struggle to repeat one of the great sporting comebacks in the America's Cup history. Ezra Shaw/Getty Images North America/Getty Images Spithill and his crew overturned an 8-1 deficit four years ago in San Francisco Bay eventually winning 9-8 against challengers Emirates Team New Zealand. This year, Oracle Team USA's hopes are fading fast -- they trail 6-1. Ezra Shaw/Getty Images North America/Getty Images Australian yachtsman Spithill has found himself under increasing pressure with some suggesting he should hand over the helm of the Or...

item.title: Ben Ainslie's wife pens heartfelt open letter to her husband, a fortnight before the start of the America's Cup - The Telegraph
item.description:
Ben Ainslie's wife pens heartfelt open letter to her husband, a fortnight before the start of the America's Cup  The Telegraph

With a fortnight to go until the 35th America's Cup gets under way in Bermuda, Ben Ainslie's wife, Georgie, writes an emotional open letter calling on her husband to draw strength from former glories. Darling husband, I’m sure you’ve seen it and have most likely been ignoring it, but there is a countdown clock that’s been quietly ticking away in the middle of Front Street, in Hamilton, since we arrived here in Bermuda. It has been telling us, whether you’ve wanted to listen or not, how long we have to go until the AC35 begins. When we first arrived it said we had 150 days left. Now we are ...

item.title: The politics of a grudge match: How a New Zealand win could change the face of the America's Cup - The Telegraph
item.description:
The politics of a grudge match: How a New Zealand win could change the face of the America's Cup  The Telegraph

It is sometimes said that sport and politics do not mix. In the America's Cup, however, the mad melange is part of the fun. After an unnecessarily long run-up, the competition's 35th edition is into the final stretch. But the next few days will do more than decide this year's winner. New Zealand are the only team who are not signed up to a new protocol put forward by current Defenders Oracle Team USA. The protocol sets out how future Cup's will work, but it could all be rendered redundant if the Kiwis win. The Deed of Gift, the competition's constitution, states that the only the Cup's Defe...

item.title: OracleVoice: Hope Springs Eternal For ORACLE TEAM USA, Despite 3-0 America's Cup Deficit - Forbes Now
item.description:
OracleVoice: Hope Springs Eternal For ORACLE TEAM USA, Despite 3-0 America's Cup Deficit  Forbes Now

ROYAL NAVAL DOCKYARD, BERMUDA—Emirates Team New Zealand took a 3-0 lead over two-time defending champion ORACLE TEAM USA on Day #2 of the America’s Cup Match finals, living up to the cliché that the team that makes the fewest mistakes sailing the fastest boat usually wins the race. But despite the considerable deficit, ORACLE TEAM USA skipper Jimmy Spithill expressed confidence that the team could rebound, drawing on the lessons of the team’s historic come-from-behind America’s Cup victory against the Kiwis four years ago. The America’s Cup Match finals resume next weekend, giving ORACLE TE...

item.title: America's Cup through the lens of a Formula One photographer - The Telegraph
item.description:
America's Cup through the lens of a Formula One photographer  The Telegraph

22 May 2017 America's Cup through the lens of a Formula One photographer Previous slideNext slide1 of 10View AllSkip Ad As the six teams line up in Bermuda, celebrated F1 photographer Darren Heath gets a first glimpse of the world’s fastest sailing boats. Darren Heath Back to image

item.title: The anatomy of a capsize: how did a multi-million dollar America's Cup boat end up in the drink? - The Telegraph
item.description:
The anatomy of a capsize: how did a multi-million dollar America's Cup boat end up in the drink?  The Telegraph

The world's finest sailors, the best engineers and technology that money can buy and yet you still end up with your arse in the air having just taken a nose-first dunk in the drink. How? Human error Emirates Team New Zealand helmsman Peter Burling immediately accepted responsibility for the incident, but Sir Ben Ainslie's tactical manoeuvring may have played its part - though that's not to suggest Ainslie played dirty or left the Kiwis in an unfairly tight spot. Ainslie, who has been a master of the art of pre-starts throughout the competition, played it hard but fair. 'The hook''The hook' ...

item.title: Blair Tuke targets unprecedented sailing triple - CNN
item.description:
Blair Tuke targets unprecedented sailing triple  CNN

Just two months on from lifting the oldest trophy in sport, Blair Tuke is already setting his sights on something no sailor has ever achieved. The Kiwi has proved his credentials in both fleet racing and match racing -- winning Olympic gold in the 49er class, and the 35th Americas Cup with Emirates Team New Zealand. Now he's going global, turning his attentions to the Volvo Ocean Race (VOR). "It's a different boat, but a lot of the same principles of sailing are here," Tuke tells CNN, having joined Spanish team MAPFRE. "You go out and make the boat go fast, day in day out without any respit...

item.title: After Bermuda Loss, Land Rover Re-Ups Support For America's Cup British Team - Forbes Now
item.description:
After Bermuda Loss, Land Rover Re-Ups Support For America's Cup British Team  Forbes Now

In a car 60mph is nothing special but in a large sailboat, such a pace is insanely fast. In Bermuda this year, the America’s Cup racing catamarans were duking it out at these speeds and one of them owed its prowess in part to the automotive world. Land Rover-backed BAR team shows its form in Bermuda, with Maltese Falcon, the world’s largest privately owned vessel in the background. British luxury SUV maker, Land Rover, played a key role in the development of the America’s Cup boat entered by Britain’s Sir Ben Ainslie Racing (BAR) sailing team. For a rookie team, BAR had a successful run-up ...

item.title: New Zealand embrace pedal power in America's Cup bid - The Telegraph
item.description:
New Zealand embrace pedal power in America's Cup bid  The Telegraph

It has been one of the major talking points ahead of the 35th America’s Cup, with some arguing that it could be a game-changer and others dismissing its significance. New Zealand, though, have fired out a warning to their rivals on the eve of competition, suggesting the other teams have made an error by not ­incorporating bike technology on to their boats and insisting that, if the rules remain the same, eventually they will all be copying them and using leg power to charge their hydraulic systems. Tim Meldrum, the mechanical designer at Emirates Team New Zealand who has led the Kiwis’ cycl...

item.title: From old school schooners to 'flying' catamarans: the evolution of America's Cup boats in pictures - The Telegraph
item.description:
From old school schooners to 'flying' catamarans: the evolution of America's Cup boats in pictures  The Telegraph

16 May 2017 From old school schooners to 'flying' catamarans: the evolution of America's Cup boats in pictures Previous slideNext slide1 of 14View AllSkip Ad The 50-foot catamarans that will be racing around Bermuda’s Great Sound during the 35th America's Cup are unrecognisable from their genteel, timber ancestors. The days of sleek monohulls helmed by commodores in white trousers may be long gone, but the evolution of the boat-making craft is beautifully documented by over 150 years of paintings and photographs. Back to image

item.title: The America's Cup J-Class racing yacht: in a class of its own and making a comeback - The Telegraph
item.description:
The America's Cup J-Class racing yacht: in a class of its own and making a comeback  The Telegraph

It’s not hard to tell when you’re in close proximity to a J-Class yacht. First, most of the sky is obliterated by 10,000sq ft of sail (the equivalent of nearly four tennis courts) hoisted on a 175ft mast. Then the air is sucked out from around you as the wind is drawn up between the sails. And then you hear the hiss…While most modern boats splash or crash through the sea, with a 'bone in their teeth’, the J-Class hiss. It’s thanks to that incredibly pointy, overhanging bow and the slender hull, which cuts through the water at 12 knots, leaving barely a ripple behind it. That hiss might soun...

item.title: Volvo Ocean Race: Foiling monohulls and multihulls to feature in revamp - CNN
item.description:
Volvo Ocean Race: Foiling monohulls and multihulls to feature in revamp  CNN

One hull or two? That's the debate that has raged around the future design of Volvo Ocean Race boats - should they be monohull or multihull? In the end organizers have opted for both in a radical development for sailing's premier around-the-world race. After the 2017-18 edition, the event will use 60ft "foil-assisted" monohulls for the offshore legs with a 32-50ft foiling catamaran for the in-port races. "Three hulls, but not what you might have imagined," Volvo Ocean Race chief executive Mark Turner told a news conference in Gothenburg Thursday. The next generation Volvo Ocean Race boats w...

item.title: Officine Panerai Cruises Into The 35th America's Cup Final With Five Sailing-Themed Watches - Forbes Now
item.description:
Officine Panerai Cruises Into The 35th America's Cup Final With Five Sailing-Themed Watches  Forbes Now

Panerai Luminor 1950 Regatta Oracle Team USA 3 Days Chrono Flyback Automatic Titanio (200-piece limited edition, $17,900) Earlier this year, Italian luxury watch manufacturer Officine Panerai revealed five new watches in honor of its recently announced partnership with the 35th America’s Cup and two of the teams racing for the world’s oldest sporting trophy: defender Oracle Team USA and challenger SoftBank Team Japan. The America’s Cup heads into the final rounds this weekend in Bermuda, and racing will take place every weekend from now until June 26, 2017. Though Panerai has often been ass...

item.title: Aussies taste victory and defeat in America's Cup - ABC News
item.description:
Aussies taste victory and defeat in America's Cup  ABC News

The America's Cup may have pitted New Zealand against the might of the United States but it was two Australians who went head to head as the respective skippers in sailing's most prestigious race. Bendigo-born Glenn Ashby skippered Team New Zealand in Bermuda's Great Sound to a crushing 7-1 victory over Team USA, who were guided by Sydney's Jimmy Spithill. The win exorcised the demons from four years ago in San Francisco, when Team New Zealand squandered an 8-1 lead over Spithill's Team USA to lose the challenge series 9-8. Ashby, who is the sole remaining member of the Team New Zealand's 2...

item.title: This has been a frustrating America's Cup journey but it's not over yet - The Telegraph
item.description:
This has been a frustrating America's Cup journey but it's not over yet  The Telegraph

The racing on Friday was interesting. I’m happy for Iain Percy that he and Artemis have made it through because they had some frustrations earlier in the week with the penalty that went against them in that incredibly close race against Emirates New Zealand. I was sorry to see Groupama Team France knocked out of the qualifiers, though. Franck Cammas and his team have shown themselves to be great competitors through this America’s Cup cycle. They are a strong team who punched above their weight and can only get stronger in the next cycle. As for us, we have two more races in the qualifiers –...

item.title: OracleVoice: America's Cup Boats Draft Moore's Law Technology Curve - Forbes Now
item.description:
OracleVoice: America's Cup Boats Draft Moore's Law Technology Curve  Forbes Now

The boats that competed for the 32nd America’s Cup, off Valencia, Spain, in 2007, weren’t much faster than the ones Queen Victoria watched sail down the Solent strait during the first Cup race almost 170 years ago. But the yacht-technology advances of the last several years have been nothing short of astounding. New craft-lifting, drag-reducing hydrofoils and wingsails, augmented by ultra-responsive control systems and space-age aerodynamics, have nearly quintupled boat speeds while improving maneuverability. The catamarans that will fly above water in the 35th America’s Cup qualifiers, pla...

item.title: America's Cup: Team New Zealand one point from glory after win over Oracle - The Guardian
item.description:
America's Cup: Team New Zealand one point from glory after win over Oracle  The Guardian

Helmsman Peter Burling and his underdog Emirates Team New Zealand won two races on Sunday to reach match point in the America’s Cup against Jimmy Spithill and two-time defending champion Oracle Team USA. Now the New Zealanders need to avoid the kind of soul-crushing collapse that kept them from winning the oldest trophy in international sports four years ago. Burling, who at 26 could become the youngest helmsman to hoist sailing’s greatest prize, steered his red-and-black, 50-foot foiling catamaran to victories of 12 seconds in Race 7 and 30 seconds in Race 8 on the Great Sound. His team mo...

item.title: Ben Ainslie’s GB crew dig deep to earn America’s Cup play-off place - The Guardian
item.description:
Ben Ainslie’s GB crew dig deep to earn America’s Cup play-off place  The Guardian

Sir Ben Ainslie bounced back from a defeat to end Thursday’s racing at the America’s Cup on a high by securing a play-off place. The British crew retired in their first race of the day with New Zealand’s victory already secured but later dug deep to see off France in a thriller. The victory sent Land Rover BAR into their rest day on Friday safe in the knowledge they had earned themselves another week in Bermuda. Related: America’s Cup 2017: Ben Ainslie’s bid for sailing glory explained | Barry Glendenning Ainslie’s bid to qualify for the main event had been delayed after light winds forced ...

item.title: Nathan Outteridge denies Swedes have target on their backs after practice racing form - The Telegraph
item.description:
Nathan Outteridge denies Swedes have target on their backs after practice racing form  The Telegraph

Artemis Racing Swedenskipper Nathan Outteridge played down talk that his team had a target on their backs following their stand-out performances in practice racing on Bermuda's Great Sound. The Swedes have surprised many with their strong form in the weeks running up to the start of the America's Cup, which has been postponed until Saturday after gale force winds were forecast for Friday afternoon. But Outteridge denied suggestions that other teams may attempt to unsettle the Swedes in their opening races. “I don’t think we have a target on our back. The races have been super close and we'v...

item.title: Great Britain’s Land Rover BAR fall 2-0 behind in America’s Cup pursuit - The Guardian
item.description:
Great Britain’s Land Rover BAR fall 2-0 behind in America’s Cup pursuit  The Guardian

Great Britain’s Land Rover BAR were dealt a severe blow in their attempt to reach the America’s Cup after a failure in their wing handed Team New Zealand the initiative in Bermuda. Sir Ben Ainslie’s syndicate suffered damage to the wing in the opening race as they rounded the leeward gate, forcing them to retire from the opening race of the challenger semi-finals. They were unable to complete the repairs to their boat in the available time and they forfeited the second race as a result to hand the New Zealanders – who chose to take on the British crew – a 2-0 lead in the first-to-five races...

item.title: America's Cup: 'there is no second place' - a history of the oldest trophy in international sport - The Telegraph
item.description:
America's Cup: 'there is no second place' - a history of the oldest trophy in international sport  The Telegraph

The events calendar of the Golden Gate Yacht Club (GGYC), overlooking San Francisco Bay, has a distinctly homely sound: there’s Thirsty Thursdays, a Cioppino night, a Cinco de Mayo lunch, and the weekly Friday Night Beer Can Race. Even its popular winter series has a kooky name: the Manuel Fagundes Seaweed Soup Regatta. And then, every few years, there’s the America’s Cup. The story of how yachting’s most prestigious prize – also reputedly the world’s oldest sporting trophy – ended up at this unassuming sailing club is the stuff of America’s Cup legend. In the year 2000, Silicon Valley bill...

item.title: 17 best places to visit in 2017 - CNN
item.description:
17 best places to visit in 2017  CNN

17 places to visit in 2017 -- As Canada turns 150 this year, what better place to visit than Charlottetown on Prince Edward Island? It's where the Canadian nation was born. Renault Philippe/Hemis/ZUMAPRESS.com Bermuda -- This British Overseas Territory will host the America's Cup sailing competition for the first time ever, attracting even more fans to this beautiful archipelago. Mike Theiss/National Geographic/Getty Images Colombia --The pope's planned visit to Colombia will draw even more attention to this booming South American country, including the historical area of the city of Cartag...

item.title: What a shot! 33 amazing sports photos - CNN
item.description:
What a shot! 33 amazing sports photos  CNN

Kevin Durant waves to the crowd in Oakland, California, during the Golden State Warriors' victory parade on Thursday, June 15. Durant was the NBA Finals' most valuable player as the Warriors defeated Cleveland to win their second title in three seasons. Kyle Terada/USA TODAY Sports Keelan Cole makes a one-handed catch during the Jacksonville Jaguars' minicamp on Tuesday, June 13. The NFL season begins in early September. Bob Mack/The Florida Times-Union/AP Brooks Koepka kisses his trophy after winning the US Open on Sunday, June 18. Koepka won by four shots to collect the first major title ...

item.title: America's Cup: 'Superhuman' sailors in 'brutal' workouts - CNN
item.description:
America's Cup: 'Superhuman' sailors in 'brutal' workouts  CNN

Some see sailing as a sedate sport, but you know the game has changed when the "athletes" are described as "superhumans" and undergo special forces training. That's just what Oracle Team USA has been doing to cope with the demands of sailing the new high-tech breed of America's Cup catamarans. Teams argue that to keep the cutting-edge craft "flying" on their hydrofoils, crews in this year's 35th America's Cup will be fitter, faster and stronger than ever before. Artemis Racing chief Iain Percy, a two-time Olympic gold medalist, described sailing these 50-miles-per-hour missiles as "beyond p...

item.title: Sir Ben Ainslie vows Land Rover BAR will bounce back after latest defeat - The Guardian
item.description:
Sir Ben Ainslie vows Land Rover BAR will bounce back after latest defeat  The Guardian

Sir Ben Ainslie has vowed to “come back fighting” after Land Rover BAR were surprisingly beaten by Groupama Team France in the America’s Cup Qualifiers on Monday. The British team won their opening race against Sweden’s Artemis Racing on Saturday but their momentum in Bermuda has faltered with four straight defeats – two of them on Sunday – with the latest coming despite a promising start. However, a drop in the breeze and a critical error on the first tack by the six-man British crew, handed France the initiative as they claimed a 53-second victory. Related: America’s Cup 2017: Ben Ainslie...

item.title: Sir Ben Ainslie's America's Cup qualification hopes in doubt after fourth successive defeat - The Telegraph
item.description:
Sir Ben Ainslie's America's Cup qualification hopes in doubt after fourth successive defeat  The Telegraph

Sir Ben Ainslie admitted his team were now “in a fight” to avoid being the first team to be dumped out of the America’s Cup after yet another defeat– their fourth in succession – out in Bermuda on Monday, this time at the hands of Groupama Team France. This was not at all how things were meant to go. France were supposed to be the America’s Cup’s whipping boys. They were the last team to launch, they have the smallest budget, they finished bottom of the America’s Cup World Series, they had only one practice boat, their Cup boat is a refurbished version of its practice boat. Yet they are pro...

item.title: U.S. secure first win of America's Cup, trail New Zealand 4-1 - Reuters
item.description:
U.S. secure first win of America's Cup, trail New Zealand 4-1  Reuters

By Alexander Smith and Tessa Walsh HAMILTON, Bermuda (Reuters) - Defending champions Oracle Team USA clawed their way back into the America's Cup on Saturday with a much-needed win over Emirates Team New Zealand to reduce their deficit to 4-1 in the first-to-seven final. The U.S. victory in the second race of the day gave the team backed by billionaire Oracle founder Larry Ellison hope of another comeback against New Zealand. Oracle Team USA won the cup in 2013 in San Francisco after staging one of the most astonishing sporting comebacks against New Zealand, winning 9-8 after having been 8-...

item.title: How technology helped the America's Cup hit the mainstream - CNN
item.description:
How technology helped the America's Cup hit the mainstream  CNN

When the 2017 America's Cup final match gets under way on Saturday, sailing's ultimate event will have hard job matching the drama and impact of the 2013 edition. An incredible comeback from the Larry Ellison-backed Oracle Team USA to defeat Emirates Team New Zealand was as dramatic as anything in the long history of sport's oldest trophy, and unlikely to be replicated when the two crews meet again on the waters of Bermuda to decide the destination of the Auld Mug. The 2013 event also marked the competition's coming of age, the moment it went from a race for sailing enthusiasts to an occasi...

item.title: The 35th America's Cup in pictures - CNN
item.description:
The 35th America's Cup in pictures  CNN

The 35th America's Cup is underway in the azure blue waters of Bermuda's Great Sound. Over the coming weeks, four teams will take to the waves to challenge for the right to face off against reigning champions, Oracle Team USA. Jimmy Spithill, skipper of the US team, competes during the second day of racing on May 28. AFP/AFP/AFP/Getty Images First staged in 1851, the America's Cup is the oldest trophy in international sport. AFP/AFP/AFP/Getty Images An invasion of 200,000 fans is expected for the event, with many boarding on cruise ships. Here, the Land Rover BAR team, skippered by Ben Ains...

item.title: New Zealand must keep multihulls as they lead America's Cup into new era - The Telegraph
item.description:
New Zealand must keep multihulls as they lead America's Cup into new era  The Telegraph

That was not quite the Cup matchup we anticipated. I said before it began that I would not want to be a betting man. I really did think it would be a closely fought contest. I certainly did not envisage a 7-1 thumping of Oracle Team USA. I don’t think anyone did, apart from perhaps the Kiwis themselves. New Zealand absolutely deserved to win, though. They were extremely aggressive with their boat design, taking big risks, and in the end they were rewarded for that. It was a ruthless display. Who dares wins. You have to give them credit, particularly given the manner in which they lost in Sa...

item.title: Simon van Velthooven: Pedal power on the high seas - CNN
item.description:
Simon van Velthooven: Pedal power on the high seas  CNN

Simon van Velthooven has swapped the track for the water as he bids to pedal Emirates Team New Zealand to America's Cup glory. Hagen Hopkins/Getty Images AsiaPac/Getty Images Van Velthooven is part of a team that has swapped traditional grinders turned by hand for pedal power. Richard Hoddder/Richard Hodder / Emirates Team New Zealand A bronze medalist in the Keirin at the London 2012 Olympic Games, Van Velthooven accepted an invitation from Team New Zealand after missing out on selection for Rio 2016. Phil Walter/Getty Images Europe/Getty Images "The speed's very similar, and I'm still ped...
